Graphical abstract Photocatalytic transformation of organic materials is widely known as one of the most favorable procedures to fabricate value-added compounds. Achieving considerable selectivity along with targeted conversion is the most challenging issue in these reactions and requires design and development of new photocatalysts. In this review, we summarized latest developments in photocatalytic synthesis of organic compounds over graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4)-based composites. Strategies including copolymerization, engineering the structure of photocatalyst, metal and nonmetal doping, design of heterojunctions and ternary nanocomposites based on g-C3N4 to progress photocatalytic activity were highlighted, with perspectives, challenges and future directions also discussed. Keywords Organic transformation g-C3N4 Photocatalysts Value-added compounds 1 Introduction Industrial development and population growth have led to raising widespread concerns about environmental policies. The restriction in fossil fuels availability and greenhouse effect are becoming pressing issues. To address these issues, chemical manufacturers need to consider energy costs, improve green processing methods and utilize solar energy as an abundant and renewable energy resource [1–5]. Semiconductor-based heterogeneous photocatalysis, has attracted a great deal of attention by researchers as a promising technique to supply alternative energy and response the demand for environmental pollutions treatment [6–10]. Kinetic models have been developed and spectroscopic studies employed to interpret mechanistic behavior of the photocatalytic systems [11]. For the first time in 1912, Giacomo Ciamician suggested application of photochemical science in organic synthesis [12]. Since that for a long time, using photochemistry in degradation of environmental pollutants and water splitting was common but in the domain of organic synthesis has not attracted researchers attention due to unselectivity of the process [13,14]. However, recently some higher value chemicals have been produced by means of selectively oxidizing or reducing substrates by choosing appropriate heterogeneous photocatalysis and visible light [2,15–19]. Despite the fact that evaluation of efficiency in photocatalytic processes is often done based on overall and apparent quantum yield calculations (Eqs. (1) and (2)), usually this procedure is not utilized for organic synthesis reactions because due to their complex mechanisms the exact determination of reacted electrons number is difficult. Therefore, the most common method for efficiency evaluation is measuring conversion, yield and selectivity (Eqs. (3)–(5)) [20]. Compared to the other classic methods, using heterogeneous photocatalysis demands milder conditions and the principal issue for these reactions is to find effective factors and optimizing them in order to have appropriate selectivity. The main point in achieving improved selectivity is to cut down the mineralization of substrates. For this purpose, factors affecting selectivity and efficiency of the reactions including type and structure of the catalyst, solvent, energy and wavelength of incident light, etc., were investigated and many case studies on different photocatalysts have been operated for achieving fine chemicals [21–23]. Partial oxidation of alcohols to their corresponding carbonyls, oxidation of aromatics, carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom coupling, esterification and epoxidation reactions have been studied (Scheme 1 ) [24–27]. Wu et al. had applied CdSe quantum dots in the presence of 3-mercaptopropionic acid as relay reagent for oxidation of water-insoluble alcohols with high efficiency and selectivity [28]. A number of other photocatalysts such as metal-organic frameworks [29], BiOCl, BiOBr [30,31] and CdWO4 [32] have been used for oxidation of benzyl alcohol, aliphatic alcohols and benzene. Xie and coworkers investigated methanol conversion to ethylene glycol over MoS2/CdS nanocomposites. Mechanistic studies demonstrate that activation of C–H bonds in methanol gives rise to formation of hydroxymethyl radicals and subsequently CC coupling results in formation of Ethylene glycol with high efficiency and 90 % selectivity [33]. Triantafyllidis et al. employed 1D MnO2 nanorods for partial oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-diformylfuran. Affecting factors such as solvent and irradiation wavelength have been thoroughly studied and revealed that the reactivity of the photocatalyst had noticeably improved by using acetonitrile as a less polar organic solvent in comparison with water and the UV light is more beneficial compared to visible light [34]. Core-shell photocatalysts, due to appropriate stability of their structure, improving separation of photogenerated charge carriers and providing interface between semiconductors and components have received research attention in the field of organic transformation [6]. Zhu et al. reported selective epoxidation of various alkenes over Cu@TiN photocatalyst under visible light irradiation. In this study affecting parameters, including irradiation intensity and wavelength, solvent and reaction temperature were investigated. Findings reported that Cu@TiN photocatalyst has outstanding selectivity for epoxidation of alkenes [35]. Xu and coworkers fabricated 3D core-shell structure of Au-SiO2@TiO2 as an efficient broadband light driven catalyst and taking the advantages of surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect, employed it for photoreduction of aromatic nitro compounds and conversion of benzylic alcohols. Results shows that 92 % reduction of 4-nitro aniline is achieved over 5% Au-SiO2@TiO2 composite [36]. In another work, they have designed multiple metal-semiconductor and metal-metal heterojunctions using Au nanorods, Pt nanoparticles and CdS. The prepared Au-Pt@CdS photocatalyst was used for simultaneous conversion of alcohol to aldehyde and H2 production [37]. Apart from 3D structured photocatalysts, great research have been also conducted on two-dimensional ones. Graphene, as a 2D structured photocatalyst, due to its unique characteristics such as electrical conductivity and optical properties, has attracted a lot of attention. Graphene based nanocomposites, which have applied in the field of photocatalysis categorized in four types including composites of graphene with organics such as porphyrins and metal–organic frameworks, graphene-semiconductor, graphene-metal and graphene oxide composites. It has been proved that these composites have also excellent photocatalytic performance in selective organic transformation reactions namely reduction of nitroaromatics and alcohols oxidation [38–40]. Indeed, most of the photocatalysts that have been used in this area have wide band gap and are photoactive at UV region or includes expensive metallic nanoparticles. Therefore, design and fabricating of effective, stable and novel visible-light-driven (VLD) photocatalysts are the main challenges in this area of science [41–45]. Recently, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has received increasing interest as a promising VLD photocatalyst to perform selective photocatalytic reactions owing to its excellent chemical and physical properties, large surface area, interfacial charge separation and transport, and facility of modification [46–48]. In 2006, the research group of Antonietti introduced this semiconductor as catalyst and then, in 2009, as heterogeneous photocatalyst for H2 evolution [49,50]. Afterwards, this polymeric semiconductor has received great deal of attention because of its unique characteristics such as suitable electronic structure, thermal and chemical stability, easy preparation and appropriate band gap [51–55]. As a fascinating metal-free semiconductor, it has been utilized in various scientific areas (Scheme 2 ). Worldwide industrialization and urbanization have led to increase in waste discharges. The global environmental pollution including greenhouse gas and nitrogen oxides emissions as well as water pollution is reaching worrying proportions. In this regard, graphitic carbon nitride-based materials have attracted great deal of attention as visible light-responsive photocatalysts for organic pollutants degradation [53,56,65,66,57–64], microbial degradation [67–69], CO2 reduction [70–75] and NOx abatement [76–80]. Increasing in global energy consumption gives rise to climate change and contribute to energy crisis, which is a major concern nowadays. Hydrogen production through photocatalytic water splitting is a viable alternative for future energy demand and environmental issues [81–83]. g-C3N4 as a metal-free semiconductor exhibits sufficient performance for hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions [84–90]. Owing to its fast charge recombination, researchers have been forced to apply some constructive approaches such as element doping, copolymerization, and exfoliation to improve photocatalytic performance [91–93]. In order to achieve reliable power sources for portable electronic devices, lithium-ion batteries have developed as rechargeable batteries. Graphitic carbon nitride as a layered soft polymer with excellent electronic structure proved as a sufficient material for electrochemical applications. In this way, various g-C3N4-based nanostructures were engineered as materials for electrocatalysis, energy storage devices [94,95], fuel cells [96–100], energy conversion [101,102], and lithium-ion batteries [103–108]. One of the good points about Li-ion batteries is that they deliver high energy densities but the major drawback is that the power densities and cycle stabilities are limited. While it is well known that the main merits of supercapacitors are their high-power density, quick charging and discharging of them, and unlimited cycling stability. Therefore, plenty of g-C3N4-based nanomaterials has been developed and utilized in supercapacitors [109–114]. Moreover, the effect of g-C3N4 nanosheets as a new modified two-dimensional graphene-like nanomaterials have been extensively investigated in electrochemical sensors and biosensors performance [115–120]. Unique physical, chemical, and biological properties of g-C3N4 as well as simple synthesis methods using more affordable precursors, encouraged researchers to explore its utilization in medicine and biology, where formerly, graphene was the main option. To fulfill the required characteristics of a proper performance in biosystems, modifications should be conducted, in order to reduce the sheet size, improve dispersity, and increase hydrophilicity. For instance, single layer g-C3N4 with small thickness used in photodynamic therapy against cancers and also employed in bioimaging. Several contributions have also demonstrated that g-C3N4 can be employed in drug extraction, bacteria disinfection, and biosensors [121–130]. By developing application of g-C3N4 in photocatalytic organic synthesis and increasing number of publications, an updated and comprehensive review is needed. In this paper, beside some catalytic reactions over carbon nitrides, we will concentrate more on different modification strategies to enhance photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4 for achieving fine chemicals. The discussed strategies are structural modifications, elemental doping, assembling of g-C3N4 with suitable semiconductors, preparation of Z-scheme heterojunctions, and noble metal/g-C3N4 heterojunction formations. 2 g-C3N4 properties Special thermal and chemical stability of carbon nitride make it fantastic candidate for direct using in various fields of sustainable chemistry. Thermogravimetric analysis demonstrated that thermally endurance of carbon nitride is up to 600 °C, while the complete decomposition occurs when the temperature rises to 750 °C [54]. Van der Waals interactions between layers lead excellent chemical resistance to acids, bases and insolubility in water and organic solvents [131]. Graphitic carbon nitride exhibits exceptional characteristic points. However, the recombination of photogenerated charges in pure g-C3N4 is speedy and photocatalytic performance is mainly relying on charge handling. In this way, some modifications applied including composites formation and introducing other components in catalyst formulation, which can lead to capture electrons and subsequently diminish recombinationof electrons and holes. To investigate the phenomena of transfer, recombination, and separation of photoinduced charge carriers in the reaction systems, the steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra of pure catalyst and its nanocomposites were measured and decreasing of emission intensity of nanocomposites attributed to increase of electron-hole separation [132–134]. Photoelectrochemical techniques such as electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and transient photocurrent responses can confirm charge carriers generation and transfer performance [135]. Time-resolved microwave conductivity (TRMC) results can also demonstrate mobile charge carriers lifetime and interpret photocatalytic quantum efficiency results [132]. Engineering materials surface and increasing specific surface area (SSA) using some strategies such as exfoliation of layered materials and synthesis of porous structures can also improve photoactivity [136]. Considering the small SSA of pure carbon nitride, many scientists have started and they are continuing to develop constructive approaches (Fig. 1 ). Some of these new developments include template utilization, physical and chemical treatment and adding gas bubble templates such as ethanol, starch and ammonium chloride, which can decompose into gases materials during thermal condensation of precursors and lead to formation of porous structure [137–139]. Utilization of these procedures for morphology manipulation contribute to SSA soaring. This phenomenon is followed by narrowing band gap energy and give rise to absorption ability as well as prevention in electron-hole recombination and consequently improves photocatalytic performance [140]. The optical properties for each system are highly dependent on its band gap, which is the energy difference between conduction band minimum (the lowest unoccupied electronic structure) and valance band maximum (the highest occupied electronic structure), and these energy states determine its responsivity to light irradiation. Therefore, it is worth mentioning that the suitable electronic properties have crucially significant roles in photocatalytic performance. Our knowledge about electronic structure of g-C3N4 is from both experimental (UV–vis spectroscopy) and theoretical (density functional theory calculations) studies. The density functional theory calculations implemented by Antonietti et al. to investigate electronic structure of different reaction intermediates and g-C3N4 along the condensation path and also the reduction and oxidation quantity of g-C3N4 conduction and valance bands [49]. As evident from Fig. 2 a, polymeric melon has a direct band gap with a non-isotropic structure at Γ point and Γ-X transitions. The results demonstrate that valance band consists predominantly Pz orbitals of nitrogen atoms while conduction band is mainly derived by carbon Pz orbitals, which provide nitrogen atoms as oxidation sites to form O2 and carbon atoms as reduction sites to form H2 in water splitting (Fig. 2(b, c)). Existence and reactivity of –C = N– and –NH2 groups in the aromatic network of carbon nitride is starting point in modification of electronic and optical characteristics. According to diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) analysis (Fig. 3 (a, b)), g-C3N4 exhibits optical wavelength around 460 nm, which corresponds to 2.7 eV band gap and it is in accordance with pale yellow color. However, practical application of g-C3N4 is restricted due to poor ability in visible-light absorption, fast recombination of photogenerated electron-holes, and low specific surface area. Narrowing band gap could be an effective strategy to overcome these drawbacks and optimize electronic structure. Elemental doping [141–143], morphology engineering [144–146], grafting of organic functional moieties [147–149] and exfoliation of bulk carbon nitride [150–152] are prominent pathways to manipulate the position of CB and VB energy levels. 2.1 Pure g-C3N4 As a practical field of science, heterogeneous photocatalysis play a vitally important rule in production of value-added chemicals. Graphitic carbon nitride, as a promising catalytic material, offers unique possibilities to selective transformations of biomass and enables various biomass conversion reactions in a one-pot way (Fig. 3(c)). Krivtsov et al. reported selective oxidation of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxaldehyde (FDC) by carbon nitride photocatalysts obtained from thermal condensation of urea, melamine, and thiourea precursors. Among them, the sample synthesized via melamine (MCN), exhibited highest graphitic carbon nitride yield and selectivity to HMF oxidation was found 30 %. Furthermore, thermal exfoliation at 450–540 °C (MCN-450, MCN-500, MCN-520 and MCN-540) implemented to overcome low surface area of graphitic carbon nitride. This procedure causes to removing uncondensed NH2 sites from catalyst surface, which were found to be unfavorable for partial oxidation of HMF, improved reaction rate and enhanced selectivity (42–45 %) to FDC production [153]. Zhang et al. studied application of mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4) as a metal-free photocatalyst. Comprehensive experiments have been conducted in order to reveal the photocatalytic properties of mpg-C3N4 in selective oxidation of sulfides at room temperature and under visible-light irradiation. The mpg-C3N4 can be easily recycled via filtration and performs in mild condition, therefore it can be considered as an environment-friendly and energy-saving material. Furthermore, according to this research, combination of aldehydes and mpg-C3N4 leads to a highly active photocatalytic system, which is not only practical in oxidation of sulfides but also illustrate high activity in oxidation of hydrocarbons, alcohols, and other organic compounds [154]. Producing chemicals from biomass using enzymes is limited due to the short process life of enzymes and their instability in industrial conditions. This inefficiency of enzyme catalysis has initiated researches in order to develop catalysis process via enzyme mimics to operate at ambient condition with the reusability option. In this regard, Deng and his coworkers reported the use of cobalt thioporphyrazine (CoPz) dispersed on g-C3N4 (CoPz/g-C3N4) as a catalyst for selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), which is an essential reaction in organic transformations. While neither g-C3N4 nor CoPz are proper catalysts individually, the substantial interaction between these two materials builds an efficient ecofriendly metal catalyst impelled with visible light, which eliminates drawbacks of CoPz and g-C3N4 components. In this research, g-C3N4 acts as a support and reduces the CoPz aggregation and makes it recoverable and improves generation of 1O2. The effect of pH is also thoroughly studied as a controlling factor and reported that high pH increases the selectivity to FDCA, while in low pH the main product is DFF (Fig. 4 ) [155]. In another study by Antonietti et al., in order to avoid the usage of any organic or metal agents, the combination of graphitic carbon nitride and N-hydroxy compounds examined for the selective allylic oxidation under mild conditions under visible light. A combination of g-C3N4 and 1-hydroxybenzotriazole (HBT) applied as an agent for selective allylic oxidation of cholesteryl acetate (CA) to 7-ketocholesteryl acetate (7-KOCA), which is essential in vitamin D3 synthesis. Four different N-hydroxy compounds were applied to fabricate the catalysts and the g-C3N4/NHPI (N-hydroxyphthalimide) was voted the best. The g-C3N4/NHPI photocatalyst offers more selectivity to production of aldehydes and ketones and results are superior especially in the oxidation of toluene and cyclohexane. According to Fig. 5 (a), after abstracting hydrogen via O 2 . - , the produced NOC radical exhibits great potential for the C–H bonds activating [156]. In an interesting research, Reisner et al. coupled organic substrate oxidation and water splitting. In this system, graphitic carbon nitride (H2NCNX) surface functionalized by cyanamide (NCNCNx) harvest light and combined with nickel (II) bis(diphosphine) (NiP). The NCNCNx−NiP hybrid system displayed great performance in simultaneously platinum-free H2 production and benzyl alcohol selective oxidation in mild condition (Fig. 5(b)). The NCNCNx prolonged photoactivity at least for 50 h of the light irradiation. Due to life-time limitation of NiP catalyst, the activity of hybrid system maintained for 24 h of irradiation [157]. 2.2 Doped g-C3N4 Depletion of fossil fuels demands development of renewable chemicals and sustainable energy sources. Because these sources are limited and emission of CO2 in the atmosphere leads to global warming and environmental issues. In this context, biomass conversion, as a promising alternative, has attracted great deal of attention [158–161]. Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is one of the important platform chemicals with ability to produce various chemicals for using in biofuels, fungicides, resins, solvents, polymers, and pharmaceuticals [162]. Li et al. prepared Fe-N-C catalyst by simultaneously pyrolysis of g-C3N4 and iron on activated carbon. The fabricated Fe-N-C, as an economic and environmental friendly catalyst, was used for hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2, 5-dimethylfuran (DMF). Effect of various parameters on conversion was investigated. According to Fig. 6 (a), after 3 h, 85.7 % of 2,5-dimethylfuran was achieved at 240 °C and 5-methylfurfural was known as the intermediate [163]. Due to conjugated electron distribution, the basicity characteristic of pure g-C3N4 is slightly low. Several strategies have been employed for improving basicity of g-C3N4 including treatment with t-ButOK or KOH and doping fluorine, bromine and iodine into carbon nitride. Carbon or nitrogen atoms in the tri-s-triazine ring could be substituted by these ions. In an early report, the effect of doping boron atoms into carbon nitride on knoevenagel condensation reaction between benzaldehyde and malononitrile was investigated (Fig. 6(b)) [164]. Higher electronegativity of nitrogen in comparison with boron caused to decrease the electron conjugation in g-C3N4, which increased its basicity and subsequently increased conversion in Knoevenagel condensation reaction. The authors also evaluated reusability of the catalyst. After five consecutive reactions, decreasing in conversion was negligible, which indicated good recycling performance. Recently, Sun and coworkers prepared surface alkaline modified g-C3N4 by introducing K+ ions in amino groups of carbon nitride [165]. They studied the role of this catalyst in synthesis of benzoin from benzyl alcohol. As can be seen in Fig. 7 , benzoin as a high value-added chemical synthesized by a two-step process. Firstly selective transforming of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde and then formation of CC bond between benzaldehydes. K+ ions by prompting electronic structure and nucleophilicity of carbon nitride improved selectivity and conversion of CC coupling reaction from 4.3 % and 6.3%–97% and 90 %, respectively. In another study reported by Vinu et al., polymerization between carbon tetrachloride and ethylenediamine with applying SBA-15, as template, caused mesoporous carbon nitride (MCN) formation [166]. Afterward, Datta et al., leveraging presence of NH2 and NH groups in the structure of MCN, synthesized highly dispersed Au nanoparticles over the inner surfaces of carbon nitride support (Au-MCN) via sonication technique and without using any functionalization of MCN. Au-MCN was employed as a selective catalyst for the activation of the C–H bond of piperidine and synthesis of proparglyamines via three component (A3) coupling reactions between phenyl acetylene, piperidine, and benzaldehyde (Fig. 8 (a)). With 50 mg catalyst loading, the product yield reached 96 % after 24 h [167]. In another study, g-C3N4 nanosheets, prepared by various precursors (urea, melamine, and thiourea), were doped by phosphorous (C3N4-U-P, C3N4-M-P or C3N4-TU-P) and the resultant photocatalysts were employed to partial oxidation of benzyl alcohol, 4-methoxy benzyl alcohol, and piperonyl alcohol. It was claimed that introducing P atoms causes to decrease in band gap of carbon nitride by moving valence band and conduction band. Moreover, making defects in the structure of carbon nitride prevents recombination of charge carriers by trapping photo-induced electrons. Specific surface area of C3N4-TU-P was six times more than pristine g-C3N4. It is probably due to the reaction between by-products (CS2, H2S) and oxygen in phosphate groups and subsequently formation of volatile gases during synthesis of C3N4-TU-P sample. Using C3N4-TU-P photocatalyst in oxidation of aromatic alcohols gives highest conversion while amount of selectivity over C3N4-U-P and C3N4-M-P is higher [168]. Zhao and coworkers deposited cobalt nanoparticles over the surface of mesoporous carbon nitride support. They investigated effect of this catalyst on hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to reach aniline in the presence of ammonia-borane, as a hydrogen storage. By loading 30 %wt of Co over g-C3N4, amount of conversion reached more than 99 %. As can be seen in Fig. 8(b), Co2+/Co° species are the key factors for trapping H atoms of ammonia-borane and transferring hydrogen to unsaturated compounds such as nitrobenzene [169]. Attaching homogeneous photocatalysts over heterogeneous photoactive supports can give a solution for their high cost and reusability issues. Kumar et al. have operated this strategy for grafting cobalt bipyridine complex over nanoporous carbon nitride (Fig. 9 ). The Co@npg-C3N4 was used in direct conversion of aldehydes to esters. Presence of electron releasing functional groups (methyl, methoxy) in the structure of aldehydes improved yield of the products. Moreover, mild basic characteristic of carbon nitride caused to proceed the reaction without any necessity to add base. Formation of covalent band between azide groups of complex and alkynes in carbon nitride, and moving electrons from complex to CB of g-C3N4 increased stability and performance of this photocatalyst [170]. 2.3 g-C3N4/semiconductors composites The construction of various nanocomposites between g-C3N4 and wide band gap semiconductors (like ZnO and TiO2), and semiconductors with narrow band gap (like BiOCl, and CdS) causes to develop promising catalysts for photoconversion applications. Producing arylated heteroarenes, as fine organic materials, is exigency required due to their excellent electronic and optical properties and biomedical applications. Recently Xiaohui et al. employed lamellar structure of g-C3N4/rGO nanocomposites for producing aryl heteroarenes via direct arylation of C–H bond in heteroarenes (Fig. 10 ). Existence of oxygen-containing functional groups in rGO caused to create COC covalent bond between two components of nanocomposite and made the band gap of nanocomposite narrower than pure g-C3N4, therefore enhanced ability to absorption of visible light. On the other hand, possessing similar carbon network and conjugated π structure with sp2 hybridization, matches rGO with g-C3N4 in sandwich structure and improves photogenerated charges separation. After optimizing reaction condition, the effect of various functional groups of aryl diazonium salts on the amount of yield was investigated. It was concluded that diazonium salts containing electron acceptor groups are more promising. Moreover, these nanocomposites exhibited significant efficiency in C–H arylation of other heteroarens like thiophene [171]. Besides the feasibility of carbon nitride-based nanocomposites in addressing fine chemicals, there is a disconcerting issue in recovering these catalysts from the reaction solution. Fe3O4 is an excellent candidate for using along with carbon nitride semiconductor and is beneficial for enhancing its recyclability. Azizi et al. used magnetically separable Fe3O4@g-C3N4 nanocomposites as inexpensive catalyst for fabrication of different derivates of 4H-Pyrans (Fig. 11 (a, b)). These compounds exhibited extensive potential in pharmaceutical and biological aspects and functionalizing by amino and cyano groups makes them promising intermediates in synthesis of organic materials. In this study, preparation of 4H-chromene performed in several reactions to optimize solvent (DMF, PEG, EtOAc, MeCN) and temperature (25–80 °C). Afterward, different 1, 3-dicarbonyl compounds, malononitrile and aromatic aldehydes were employed for synthesis of Pyrans in short reaction times (30−190 min) and with appropriate yields (72–97 %). Recycling of this catalyst by an external magnet and frequently using for ten times demonstrated that there is not significant change in amount of yield [172]. In another study, Verma and coworkers designed VO@g‑C3N4 catalyst applying urea and vanadyl acetylacetonate, as precursors. The fabricated nanocomposite indicated considerable efficiency for selective oxidation of broad spectrum of primary and secondary alcohols (Fig. 12 (a)). Noncovalent interaction of VO(acac)2 with graphitic carbon nitride surface increased the number of active sites. Despite thermodynamically unfavourable conditions of reactions such as low equilibrium constant of acetals formation and decreasing in entropy, employing g-C3N4 and profiting by efficiently separation of charge carriers cause to proceed these reactions in ambient environment without using external acid. Condensation of aldehydes or ketones with alcohols for obtaining acetal products performed with a good selectivity and conversion. It was claimed that presence of oxygen molecules, position of conduction band in carbon nitride, and ·O2 − formation have vital role in proceeding of reaction. In order to prove this claim, the reaction performed in argon atmosphere and it was found that the selectivity and conversion decreased significantly [175]. Furthermore, Ansari et al. implemented high nitrogen containing mesoporous g-C3N4 (MCN) for achieving α,-carbonyl compounds under microwave irradiation. MCN with hexagonal platelet morphology is used as promising catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation of various aromatic aldehydes with ethylcyanoacetate (Fig. 12(b–f)). Knoevenagel products are well known for their bioactive properties and pharmacological applications, synthesized with yield of 75–95 % [176]. Song et al. reported one-step route for synthesis of esters using benzaldehyde and different alcohols as raw materials. They modified graphitic carbon nitride by loading tin ions. By formation of SnO2/g-C3N4 nanocomposite, tin dioxide as a suitable catalyst for esterification of aldehydes and mild oxidant, contribute in esters synthesis and synergistic effect of nanocomposite components improved these transformations [177]. Transesterification and Knoevenagel condensations are the reactions with formation of carbon-carbon bond that require basic environment for proceeding. Mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride employed as a basic photocatalyst for the first time by Wang group [178]. Since during the synthesis of catalyst, using NH4HF2 probably protonates nitrogen containing groups on the surface of carbon nitride, deprotonation of catalyst in the presence of basic solutions like K2CO3, KOH and tButOK, increased basic characteristics of mpg-C3N4 and makes it favorable for reactions between ketoesters and alcohols, malonic derivatives and different aldehydes. The FT-IR and XPS analyses demonstrated existence of free NH2 groups in the CN network and basic characteristics of the sample and the MCN-6 catalyst was employed for the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and malononitrile (Fig. 13 (a, b)). According to FTIR and XPS studies, there are four types of nitrogen species in g-C3N4 structure, containing primary amines, secondary amines, tertiary nitrogen, and pyridinic nitrogen. Based on proposed mechanism, since electron density of the primary amines nitrogen is higher, its ability for abstracting proton from metylenic groups and hence catalytic activity is the highest. With increasing urea/dicyandiamide ratio, the amount of these nitrogen species in g-C3N4 increased. On the other hand, adding a little amount of dicyandiamide to urea leads to significantly increasing in g-C3N4 yield [180]. Oxidation of aromatic alcohols has an important role in pharmaceutical, perfumery, dyestuff and chemical industries. Mesoporous g-C3N4 with high surface area (ca. 200 m2/g), appropriate conduction band and valance band potentials and basic properties employed in selective oxidation of benzyl alcohols through adsorbing and activating oxygen molecules [181]. Dai et al. designed defective carbon nitride with nitrogen vacancies in its framework through nitric acid pretreatment of melamine as precursor. Compared to pure g-C3N4, the defective sample exhibited more promising performance and selectivity (almost 100 %) in benzyl alcohol conversion (68.3 %) under simulated sunlight (Fig. 13 (c)). This improvement assigned to efficient separation of photogenerated charge carriers caused by electron-hole trapping role of nitrogen vacancies, enhancement in light harvesting by improvement in electronic structure and narrowing band gap of catalyst and increase of surface area [182]. 3 Conclusions and outlook Owing to the unique characteristics of graphitic carbon nitride, as a metal-free catalyst, it has been engaged in a wide range of scientific efforts for environmental pollution control, hydrogen production, energy conversion, energy storage devices, supercapacitors, biological and medical applications. The promotion of carbon nitride-based catalysts for organic transformations has attracted great deal of interest driven by economic and environmental motivations. As mentioned, despite many distinguishing characteristics, a number of intrinsic restrictions has limited the application of pure carbon nitride in photocatalysis processes. Furthermore, conversion of organic materials needs improvement in selectivity and product yield by designing high-performance carbon nitride-based catalysts. Thus, modified g-C3N4 can open a new window in the field of catalysis and especially heterogeneous photocatalysis. This review mainly concentrated on the recent researches in preparation, characterization, and applications of g-C3N4-based nanostructures as convincing photocatalysts, to address selectivity and yield challenges in the reaction systems. Herein, different g-C3N4 catalysed reactions summarized, and despite considerable works on operating modified g-C3N4 in photocatalysis field, there is still some shortcomings. Nonetheless, more research is required to design a suitable carbon nitride-based photocatalyst to obtain larger scale value-added products. The subsequent essays should be made to further optimize the performance of the carbon nitride-based photocatalysts and expand the reaction range. We believe that depth studies in this area can provide a new outlook towards efficient g-C3N4-based systems for the researchers to realize important organic transformations under solar irradiation. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic transformation of organic materials is widely known as one of the most favorable procedures to fabricate value-added compounds. Achieving considerable selectivity along with targeted conversion is the most challenging issue in these reactions and requires design and development of new photocatalysts. In this review, we summarized latest developments in photocatalytic synthesis of organic compounds over graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4)-based composites. Strategies including copolymerization, engineering the structure of photocatalyst, metal and nonmetal doping, design of heterojunctions and ternary nanocomposites based on g-C3N4 to progress photocatalytic activity were highlighted, with perspectives, challenges and future directions also discussed.
